column1: Schwedt (or Schwedt/Oder; German pronunciation: [ˈʃveːt]) is a town in northeastern Brandenburg
column2: Germany. With the official status of a Große kreisangehörige Stadt (major district town)
column3: it is the largest town of the Uckermark district
column4: located near the Oder River close to the border with Poland.

column1: The formerly agrarian town today has one of the largest oil refineries (PCK Raffinerie GmbH) in Germany
column2: established in 1958 and connected to the Russian Druzhba pipeline network
column3: and is the largest location of paper industry (UPM) in Europe. Most industries were located in the remote area during communist rule in the 1960s and 1970s.

column1: Large residential areas were built for the workers moving to Schwedt. About 9% of the town's flats are in prefab concrete buildings (Plattenbau) dating from the era. As many jobs were lost after German reunification and the return to market economy
column2: Schwedt has lost a quarter of its population since 1990. In recent decades
column3: Schwedt became a model town for the demolition of Plattenbau housing to combat urban decay.

column1: Schwedt is situated in the east of the historic Uckermark region stretching from the Oder to the Havel River. It is situated on a sandur at the western edge of the Oder floodplain running along the German-Polish border
column2: which in 1995 was declared as the Lower Oder Valley National Park nature reserve. Across the river and the border
column3: about 10 km (6.2 mi) to the southeast
column4: is the Polish town of Chojna (formerly Königsberg in der Neumark). The nearest German towns are Angermünde (about 18 km (11 mi) to the west) and Gartz (18 km (11 mi) down the Oder).

column2: the neighbouring village of Heinersdorf was incorporated into Schwedt
column8: and the former town Vierraden in 2003. With 200.12 km2 (77.27 sq mi) Schwedt is among the 100 largest German municipalities by area.

column2: the area had been settled by Polabian Slavs. From 937 onwards the lands of the Slavic Ukrani tribes in the west were subued by the Saxon forces of Margrave Gero and incorporated into his vast Marca Geronis
column3: while the lands east of the Oder were held by Pomeranian tribes under pressure by the Polish forces of Duke Mieszko I. The Saxon Northern March was lost in the Great Slav Rising of 983
column4: and not before 1147 the Saxon count Albert the Bear again invaded the lands on the Oder river
column5: which remained disputed between the newly established Margraviate of Brandenburg and the Pomeranian dukes.

column1: The settlement of Schwedt was first mentioned in a 1265 deed. In the course of the Brandenburg–Pomeranian conflict
column2: the Brandenburg margrave Louis II the Roman ceded it to Duke Barnim III of Pomerania in 1354. It was again besieged by the first Hohenzollern margrave Frederick I in 1434
column3: but to no avail. In 1481 the Thuringian counts of Hohnstein acquired the estates; they granted town privileges to Schwedt as well as to neighbouring Vierraden and introduced the Protestant Reformation.

column1: The rise of Schwedt came to an end with the extinction of the Hohnstein counts in 1609 and the disastrous Thirty Years' War
column2: when the town on the road from Stettin to Berlin was plundered several times. In 1631 King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden
column4: camped here on his way to the Battle of Breitenfeld. Six years later the Swedish field marshal Johan Banér set the town on fire
column5: after its citizens refused to capitulate.

column2: the Treaty of Schwedt was signed in the town.

column1: Near the end of World War II
column2: over two months of heavy fighting destroyed an estimated 85 percent of the town
column4: the Schwedter Schloss. The Soviet Army occupied Schwedt on April 26
column6: two weeks before the final defeat of Nazi Germany. During the 1960s
column7: the government of the DDR expanded housing and encouraged people to move to Schwedt
column8: a trend that ended with the fall of Communism.

column3: Major-General last in World War II
